question: Some people believe the aim of university education is to help graduates get better jobs. Others believe there are much wider benefits of university education for both individuals and society. Discuss both views and give your opinion. Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own experience or knowledge.
text: It is a common belief that higher studies provide better jobs. However, some people opine that university education offers more benefits than improved career prospects. This essay will discuss both the views in detail.

On the one hand, education provides knowledge and wisdom. Knowledge in turn boosts one’s self confidence which reflects in one’s personality. It also develops sound understanding of the subject. All of these are instrumental and crucial to acquire a suitable job. Moreover, in today’s competitive world only the best will win. Hence a person lacking proper qualification and sufficient knowledge will lose the race and lag behind. A recent study by ‘Education Forum’ magazine suggests that the service sector recruited 75% graduates and 25% undergraduates the last year. This in itself shows how important higher education is to acquire a good job.

On the other hand, education not only benefits one’s career but also changes their outlook towards life and society. Knowledge helps to develop strong reasoning and analytical skills. This empowers people with the ability to distinguish between right and wrong, good and bad. Educated people refrain themselves from blindly following any superstitious beliefs. One educated person can educate the entire family and their surroundings. Moreover, knowledge develops moral values of people and makes them responsible citizens. For instance, if we look back at history the great Raja Rammohun Roy and Vidyasagar struggled hard to eradicate social evils like SuttidahaPratha, child marriage etcetera. And they were all well qualified people who fought against such social norms which were very common those days.
To conclude, I am of the opinion that University education has a larger role to play than just provide good jobs to people.
